name: Chris Sarbora
title: Principal Software & Systems Engineer
summary: Versatile and highly accomplished Principal Software and Systems Engineer with over two decades of experience designing, developing, and optimizing complex infrastructure across XR, Android, iOS, embedded systems, Linux, and custom operating platforms. Recognized for delivering critical system components - including OpenXR APIs, bytecode compilation frameworks, kernel drivers, and over-the-air system updaters - deployed at scale in consumer devices by Meta, Facebook, and other industry leaders. Adept at technical leadership, cross-functional collaboration, and performance engineering, with a proven track record of mentoring engineers, setting organizational C++ standards, and solving high-impact technical challenges. A trusted authority in system architecture, low-level programming, and platform-level innovation, consistently driving maintainability, reliability, and cutting-edge product capabilities.

positions.title: Principal Software Engineer

highlights: Led release of Quest's Hand Interaction APIs, a standardized OpenXR extension used across XR apps and engines

Designed a novel system update architecture for AR "constellation" devices with intermittent connectivity; shipped in Meta's Orion Glasses. Successfully unblocked reliable updates for Meta's AR Glasses future.
Served as a technical lead for the XR Input team, driving long-term adoption of Spatial Input interaction models
Authored Linux kernel drivers and low-level input infrastructure to improve latency and throughput
Co-led a committee defining C++ coding standards for Reality Labs; guidance adopted by 5,000+ developers

highlights: Designing a C++ language feature to simplify and improve move semantics; prototyping in the Clang compiler

items.name: Linux ProxyFD Driver
highlights: Designed and implemented a loadable character-device driver (/dev/proxy) for Linux, enabling revocable file descriptor delegation across processes
Introduced a control/proxy FD pair model: the control FD can attach/detach a proxy FD to any existing resource, enabling fine-grained external access
Proxy FDs fully replicate the behavior of the original resource (read/write/seek/epoll/ioctl/etc), while supporting out-of-process transfer and revocation
Enables new capability-based access control patterns without destroying or recreating underlying kernel objects
Useful in container, sandbox, and service isolation scenarios where revocable delegation of restricted resources is required
